30 30

Celebrating 30 Years of AIDS Vancouver

The 30 30 campaign was created in 2013 to celebrate AIDS Vancouver’s 30th anniversary. The campaign pieces together the dynamic history of HIV in Vancouver, told by and for those who where there.

1983

1984

The Forum

In 1984

  • Michael Jackson is severely burned at the filming of a Pepsi commercial. LINK
  • The beginning of the first Crack Cocaine epidemic. LINK
  • Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau announces his retirement. LINK

Local

  • AIDS Vancouver Buddy program begins. LINK
  • AIDS Vancouver 'What are my chances?'' is circulated, which encouraged making informed choices to minimize the risk of STDs and AIDS. * Do we have the pdf for this?
  • DARE (Dedicated AIDS Resource Effort) is created to fundraise for the AIDS epidemic in Vancouver.
  • AIDS Vancouver has awareness meetings with bathhouse owners, and puts up posters saying, do not donate blood, if you are visiting this bathhouse.
  • Artibano Milito, a hemophiliac from New Westminister, passes away from a HIV+ blood infusion at age 27. The Milito family propelled an inquiry into this, mainly to dismiss any rumours that their son was a homosexual. LINK

Statistics

  • 29 reported AIDS cases in BC. LINK
  • 147 reported AIDS cases in Canada. LINK
  • 7,699 reported AIDS cases in US. LINK

Global

  • HTLV (later known as HIV) confirmed as the cause of AIDS. LINK
  • San Francisco health officials close bathhouses. LINK
  • The world's first needle exchange program is set up in Amsterdam. LINK
  • US FDA approved the Enzyme Linked Immunosorbant Assay (ELISA), the first test kit to look for virus antibodies. LINK

National

  • Gaëtan Dugas dies in his hometown, Quebec City. LINK
  • Red Cross denies link between blood bank and AIDS. Vancouver Sun Jan 16, 1984 Article No AIDS risk, says Red Cross. Dr. Noel Buskard said 'the data is just not there'.
  • The AIDS Committee of Toronto initiates the first official AIDS Awareness Week. LINK
1985

AIDS Vancouver - Prevent. Act. Support.

AIDS Vancouver plays a special role in providing quality health care to people affected by HIV/AIDS living in the Lower Mainland. It is clearly more than just a community health care organization. It is an organization whose presence and continued strength is essential to the quality for life of this community and of each individual and family who draws on its services. Our Agency is a vital community asset which everyone affected by HIV/AIDS can share, and in which we all have a stake.

Visit us at aidsvancouver.org

2013 © AIDS Vancouver
